On July 20, 2016, the Federal Supreme Court ruled that distribution system operators must divide their total energy costs proportionately between customers with a basic supply and independent customers, i.e. that the average price method must be applied. How is the average price calculated? Take the entire energy portfolio of a distribution grid operator, namely the costs of in-house production, costs from all power plant participations, energy deliveries from long-term contracts and purchases on the market. This results in the total costs. These are divided by the total volume of sales to end consumers, resulting in the average price, which is decisive for the basic supply tariff. Of the approximately 670 network operators, around 80 percent apply the average price method. 20 percent do not apply it. This involves an amount of CHF 30 to 50 million per year, which is around 2 to 3 percent of the annual turnover in the final supply. Around a dozen network operators would be substantially affected by a change of system or by the implementation of the Federal Supreme Court ruling.

According to this model, the land-based and online areas form a single unit. In principle, only one license is required to operate casino games, regardless of whether they are played physically in a casino or online. This is based on the logic of the sales channel. The land-based casino and the online offering are not seen as fundamentally different gaming offerings, but as different distribution channels, which are based on the same or at least similar casino games. We therefore have one player, i.e. one licensee, who offers its products via two channels. As part of the licensing process, a complete package is then put out to tender. Anyone applying for a license there is applying for both the casino license, the terrestrial license and the online game. This model therefore does not lead to market foreclosure, but rather creates space within the framework of the tender. However, the competition then concerns the overall packages, i.e. the land-based and online offerings.
